conclusion: Analyze velocity-time graphs to determine when objects are farthest apart.
Two velocity-time graphs labeled A and B. Graph A: zero velocity, increases linearly, decreases back to zero. Graph B: zero velocity, increases linearly, continues linearly.
Graph A: object accelerates and decelerates. Graph B: object accelerates and moves at constant velocity.
Distance from starting point is area under velocity-time graph. Graph A: max distance at max velocity. Graph B: max distance at max velocity and continues.
Graph A: max distance at peak velocity. Graph B: max distance at peak velocity and continues.
Compare times of maximum distances to determine when objects are farthest apart.
Objects are farthest apart when distance from starting point is maximized.
Objects are farthest apart at t = 3.
